]}

Mime: Mimicking Centralized Stochastic Algorithms in Federated Learning

Sai Praneeth Karimireddy
EPFL
sai.karimireddy@epfl.ch
&Martin Jaggi
EPFL
martin.jaggi@epfl.ch
&Satyen Kale
Google Research
satyenkale@google.com
&Mehryar Mohri
Google Research
mohri@google.com
&Sashank J. Reddi
Google Research
sashank@google.com
&Sebastian U. Stich
EPFL
sebastian.stich@epfl.ch
&Ananda Theertha Suresh
Google Research
theertha@google.com
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a challenging setting for optimization due to the heterogeneity of the data across different clients which can cause a client drift phenomenon. In fact, designing an algorithm for FL that is uniformly better than simple centralized training has been a major open problem thus far. In this work, we propose a general algorithmic framework, Mime, which i) mitigates client drift and ii) adapts an arbitrary centralized optimization algorithm such as momentum and Adam to the cross-device federated learning setting. Mime uses a combination of control-variates and server-level optimizer state (e.g. momentum) at every client-update step to ensure that each local update mimics that of the centralized method run on i.i.d. data. We prove a reduction result showing that Mime can translate the convergence of a generic algorithm in the centralized setting into convergence in the federated setting. Moreover, we show that, when combined with momentum-based variance reduction, Mime is provably faster than any centralized method–the first such result. We also perform a thorough experimental exploration of Mime’s performance on real world datasets.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is an increasingly important large-scale learning framework where the training data remains distributed over a large number of clients, which may be mobile phones or network sensors [36, 35, 41, 42, 27]. A server then orchestrates the clients to train a single model, here referred to as a server model, without ever transmitting client data over the network, thereby providing some basic levels of data privacy and security.

Two important settings are distinguished in FL [27, Table 1]: the cross-device and the cross-silo settings. The cross-silo setting corresponds to a relatively small number of reliable clients, typically organizations, such as medical or financial institutions. In contrast, in the cross-device federated learning setting, the number of clients may be extremely large and include, for example, all 3.5 billion active android phones [24]. Thus, in that setting, we may never make even a single pass over the entire clients’ data during training. The cross-device setting is further characterized by resource-poor clients communicating over a highly unreliable network. Together, the essential features of this setting give rise to unique challenges not present in the cross-silo setting. In this work, we are interested in the more challenging cross-device setting, for which we will formalize and study stochastic optimization algorithms. Importantly, recent advances in FL optimization, such as SCAFFOLD [30] or FedDyn [1], are not anymore applicable since they are designed for the cross-silo setting.

The problem.

The de facto standard algorithm for the cross-device setting is FedAvg [41], which performs multiple SGD updates on the available clients before communicating to the server. While this approach can reduce the frequency of communication required, performing multiple steps on the same client can lead to ‘over-fitting’ to its atypical local data, a phenomenon known as client drift [30]. This in turn leads to slower convergence and can, somewhat counter-intuitively, require larger total communication [64]. Despite significant attention received from the optimization community, the communication complexity of heterogeneous cross-device has not improved upon that of simple centralized methods, which take no local steps (aka Server-Only methods). Furthermore, algorithmic innovations such as momentum [54, 14], adaptivity [33, 70, 72], and clipping [66, 67, 71] are critical to the success of deep learning applications. The lack of a theoretical understanding of the impact of multiple client steps has also hindered adapting these techniques in a principled manner into the client updates, in order to replace the vanilla SGD update of FedAvg.

To overcome such deficiencies, we propose a new framework, Mime, that mitigates client drift and can adapt an arbitrary centralized optimization algorithm, e.g. SGD with momentum or Adam, to the federated setting. In each local client update, Mime uses global optimizer state, e.g. momentum or adaptive learning rates, and an SVRG-style correction to mimic the updates of the centralized algorithm run on i.i.d. data. This optimizer state is computed only at the server level and kept fixed throughout the local steps, thereby avoiding overfitting to the atypical local data of any single client.

Contributions.

We summarize our main results below.

  • •

    Mime framework. We formalize the cross-device federated learning problem, and propose a new framework Mime that can adapt arbitrary centralized algorithms to this setting.

  • •

    Convergence result. We prove a result showing that Mime successfully reduces client drift. We also prove that the convergence of any generic algorithm in the centralized setting translates convergence of its Mime version in the federated setting.

  • •

    Speed-up over centralized methods. By carefully tracking the bias introduced due to multiple local steps, we prove that Mime with momentum-based variance reduction (MVR) can beat a lower bound for centralized methods, thus breaking a fundamental barrier. This is the first such result in FL, and also the first general result showing asymptotic speed-up due to local steps.

  • •

    Empirical validation. We propose a simpler variant, MimeLite, with an empirical performance similar to Mime. We report the results of thorough experimental analysis demonstrating that both Mime and MimeLite indeed converge faster than FedAvg.

Related work.

Analysis of FedAvg: Much of the recent work in federated learning has focused on analyzing FedAvg. For identical clients, FedAvg coincides with parallel SGD, for which [73] derived an analysis with asymptotic convergence. Sharper and more refined analyses of the same method, sometimes called local SGD, were provided by [51], and more recently by [52], [44], [32], and [65], for identical functions. Their analysis was extended to heterogeneous clients in [63, 69, 30, 32, 34]. [11] derived a tight characterization of FedAvg with quadratic functions and demonstrated the sensitivity of the algorithm to both client and server step sizes. Matching upper and lower bounds were recently given by [30] and [64] for general functions, proving that FedAvg can be slower than even SGD for heterogeneous data, due to the client-drift.

Comparison to Scaffold: For the cross-silo setting where the number of clients is relatively low, [30] proposed the Scaffold algorithm, which uses control-variates (similar to SVRG) to correct for client drift. However, their algorithm crucially relies on stateful clients which repeatedly participate in the training process. FedDyn [1] reduces the communication requirements, but also requires persistent stateful clients. In contrast, we focus on the cross-device setting where clients may be visited only once during training and where they are stateless (and thus Scaffold and FedDyn are inapplicable). This is akin to the difference between the finite-sum (corresponding to cross-silo) and stochastic (cross-device) settings in traditional centralized optimization [37].

Comparison to FedAvg and variants: [25] and [62] observed that using server momentum significantly improves over vanilla FedAvg. This idea was generalized by [46], who replaced the server update with an arbitrary optimizer, e.g. Adam. However, these methods only modify the server update while using SGD for the client updates. Mime, on the other hand, ensures that every local client update resembles the optimizer e.g. Mime would apply momentum in every client update and not just at the server level. Beyond this, [38] proposed to add a regularizer to ensure client updates remain close. However, this may slow down convergence (cf. Fig. 4 and [30, 61]). Other orthogonal directions which can be combined with Mime include tackling computation heterogeneity, where some clients perform many more updates than others [61], improving fairness by modifying the objective [42, 39], incorporating differential privacy [19, 2, 56], Byzantine adversaries [45, 60, 29], secure aggregation [8, 23], etc. We defer additional discussion to the extensive survey by [27].

2 Problem setup

This section formalizes the problem of cross-device federated learning [27]. Cross-device FL is characterized by a large number of client devices like mobile phones which may potentially connect to the server at most once. Due to their transient nature, it is not possible to store any state on the clients, precluding an algorithm like Scaffold. Furthermore, each client has only a few samples, and there is wide heterogeneity in the samples across clients. Finally, communication is a major bottleneck and a key metric for optimization in this setting is the number of communication rounds.

Thus, our objective will be to minimize the following quantity within the fewest number of client-server communication rounds:

f​(𝒙)=𝔼i∼𝒟⁡[fi​(𝒙):=1ni​∑ν=1nifi​(𝒙;ζi,ν)].𝑓𝒙subscript𝔼similar-to𝑖𝒟assignsubscript𝑓𝑖𝒙1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜈1subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙subscript𝜁𝑖𝜈f(\bm{x})=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{i\sim\mathcal{D}}\Big{[}f_{i}(\bm{x}):=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{\nu=1}^{n_{i}}f_{i}(\bm{x};\zeta_{i,\nu})\Big{]}\,. (1)

Here, fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} denotes the loss function of client i𝑖i and {ζi,1,…,ζi,ni}subscript𝜁𝑖1…subscript𝜁𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖\{\zeta_{i,1},\ldots,\zeta_{i,n_{i}}\} its local data. Since the number of clients is extremely large, while the size of each local data is rather modest, we represent the former as an expectation and the latter as a finite sum. In each round, the algorithm samples a subset of clients (of size S𝑆S) and performs some updates to the server model. Due to the transient and heterogeneous nature of the clients, it is easy to see that the problem becomes intractable with arbitrarily dissimilar clients. Thus, it is necessary to assume bounded dissimilarity across clients.

  1. (A1)

    G2superscript𝐺2G^{2}-BGV or bounded inter-client gradient variance: there exists G≥0𝐺0G\geq 0 such that

    𝔼i∼𝒟⁡[∥∇fi​(𝒙)−∇f​(𝒙)∥2]≤G2,∀𝒙.subscript𝔼similar-to𝑖𝒟superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙∇𝑓𝒙2superscript𝐺2for-all𝒙\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{i\sim\mathcal{D}}[\lVert\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla f(\bm{x})\rVert^{2}]\leq G^{2}\,,\ \forall\bm{x}\,.

Next, we also characterize the variance in the Hessians.

  1. (A2)

    δ𝛿\delta-BHV or bounded Hessian variance: Almost surely, the loss function of any client i𝑖i satisfies

    ∥∇2fi​(𝒙;ζ)−∇2f​(𝒙)∥≤δ,∀𝒙.delimited-∥∥superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙𝜁superscript∇2𝑓𝒙𝛿for-all𝒙\lVert\nabla^{2}f_{i}(\bm{x};\zeta)-\nabla^{2}f(\bm{x})\rVert\leq\delta\,,\ \forall\bm{x}\,.

This is in contrast to the usual smoothness assumption that can be stated as:

  1. (A2*)

    L𝐿L-smooth: ∥∇2fi​(𝒙;ζ)∥≤L,∀𝒙,delimited-∥∥superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙𝜁𝐿for-all𝒙\lVert\nabla^{2}f_{i}(\bm{x};\zeta)\rVert\leq L\,,\ \forall\bm{x}\,, a.s. for any i𝑖i.

Note that if fi​(𝒙;ζ)subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙𝜁f_{i}(\bm{x};\zeta) is L𝐿L-smooth then ((A2)) is satisfied with δ≤2​L𝛿2𝐿\delta\leq 2L, and hence ((A2)) is weaker than ((A2*)). In realistic examples we expect the clients to be similar and hence that 𝜹≪𝑳much-less-than𝜹𝑳\bm{\delta\ll L}. In addition, we assume that f​(𝒙)𝑓𝒙f(\bm{x}) is bounded from below by f⋆superscript𝑓⋆f^{\star} and is L𝐿L-smooth, as is standard.

3 Mime framework

In this section we describe how to adapt an arbitrary centralized optimizer (referred to as the “base” algorithm) which may have internal state (e.g. momentum in SGD) to the federated learning problem (1) while ensuring there is no client-drift. Algorithm 1 describes our framework. We develop two variants, Mime and MimeLite, which consist of three components i) a base algorithm we are seeking to mimic, ii) how we compute the global (server) optimizer state, and iii) the local client updates.

Base algorithm.

We assume the centralized base algorithm we are imitating can be decomposed into two steps: an update step 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} which updates the parameters 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}, and a optimizer state update step 𝒱​(⋅)𝒱⋅\mathcal{V}(\cdot) which keeps track of global optimizer state 𝒔𝒔\bm{s}. Each step of the base algorithm ℬ=(𝒰,𝒱)ℬ𝒰𝒱\mathcal{B}=(\mathcal{U},\mathcal{V}) uses a gradient 𝒈𝒈\bm{g} to update the parameter 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} and the optimizer state 𝒔𝒔\bm{s} as follows:

𝒙←𝒙−η​𝒰​(𝒈,𝒔),𝒔←𝒱​(𝒈,𝒔).formulae-sequence←𝒙𝒙𝜂𝒰𝒈𝒔←𝒔𝒱𝒈𝒔\begin{split}\bm{x}&\leftarrow\bm{x}-\eta\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{g},\bm{s})\,,\\ \bm{s}&\leftarrow\mathcal{V}(\bm{g},\bm{s})\,.\end{split} (BaseAlg)

As an example, consider SGD with momentum (SGDm). The state in SGDm is the momentum 𝒎tsubscript𝒎𝑡\bm{m}_{t}. SGDm uses the following update steps:

𝒙t=𝒙t−1−η​((1−β)​∇fi​(𝒙t−1)+β​𝒎t−1),𝒎t=(1−β)​∇fi​(𝒙t−1)+β​𝒎t−1.formulae-sequencesubscript𝒙𝑡subscript𝒙𝑡1𝜂1𝛽∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒙𝑡1𝛽subscript𝒎𝑡1subscript𝒎𝑡1𝛽∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒙𝑡1𝛽subscript𝒎𝑡1\begin{split}\bm{x}_{t}&=\bm{x}_{t-1}-\eta\,((1-\beta)\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}_{t-1})+\beta\bm{m}_{t-1})\,,\\ \bm{m}_{t}&=(1-\beta)\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}_{t-1})+\beta\bm{m}_{t-1}\,.\end{split}

Thus, SGDm can be represented in the above generic form with 𝒰​(𝒈,𝒔)=(1−β)​𝒈+β​𝒔𝒰𝒈𝒔1𝛽𝒈𝛽𝒔\mathcal{U}(\bm{g},\bm{s})=(1-\beta)\bm{g}+\beta\bm{s} and 𝒱​(𝒈,𝒔)=(1−β)​𝒈+β​𝒔𝒱𝒈𝒔1𝛽𝒈𝛽𝒔\mathcal{V}(\bm{g},\bm{s})=(1-\beta)\bm{g}+\beta\bm{s}. Table 5 in Appendix shows how other algorithms like Adam, Adagrad, etc. can be represented in this manner. We keep the update 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} to be linear in the gradient 𝒈𝒈\bm{g}, whereas 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} can be more complicated. This implies that while the parameter update step 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} is relatively resilient to receiving a biased gradient 𝒈𝒈\bm{g} while 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} can be much more sensitive.

Compute optimizer state globally, apply locally.

When updating the optimizer state of the base algorithm, we use only the gradient computed at the server parameters. Further, they remain fixed throughout the local updates of the clients. This ensures that these optimizer state remain unbiased and representative of the global function f​(⋅)𝑓⋅f(\cdot). At the end of the round, the server performs

𝒔←𝒱​(1|𝒮|​∑i∈𝒮∇fi​(𝒙),𝒔),←𝒔𝒱1𝒮subscript𝑖𝒮∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙𝒔\displaystyle\bm{s}\leftarrow\mathcal{V}\left(\tfrac{1}{\lvert\mathcal{S}\rvert}\textstyle\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}),\ \bm{s}\right)\,,
∇fi​(𝒙)=1ni​∑ν=1ni∇fi​(𝒙;ζi,ν).∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜈1subscript𝑛𝑖∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙subscript𝜁𝑖𝜈\displaystyle\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})=\tfrac{1}{n_{i}}\textstyle\sum_{\nu=1}^{n_{i}}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x};\zeta_{i,\nu})\,. (OptState)

Note that we use full-batch gradients computed at the server parameters 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}, not client parameters 𝒚isubscript𝒚𝑖\bm{y}_{i}.

Local client updates.

Each client i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S} performs K𝐾K updates using 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} of the base algorithm and a minibatch gradient. There are two variants possible corresponding to Mime and MimeLite differentiated using colored boxes. Starting from 𝒚i←𝒙←subscript𝒚𝑖𝒙\bm{y}_{i}\leftarrow\bm{x}, repeat the following K𝐾K times

𝒚isubscript𝒚𝑖\displaystyle\bm{y}_{i} ←𝒚i−η​𝒰​(𝒈i,𝒔)←absentsubscript𝒚𝑖𝜂𝒰subscript𝒈𝑖𝒔\displaystyle\leftarrow\bm{y}_{i}-\eta\mathcal{U}(\bm{g}_{i},\bm{s}) (CltStep)

where 𝒈i←∇fi​(𝒚i;ζ)←subscript𝒈𝑖∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒚𝑖𝜁\bm{g}_{i}\leftarrow\nabla f_{i}(\bm{y}_{i};\zeta) for MimeLite, and 𝒈i←∇fi​(𝒚i;ζ)−∇fi​(𝒙;ζ)+1|𝒮|​∑j∈𝒮∇fj​(𝒙)←subscript𝒈𝑖∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒚𝑖𝜁∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙𝜁1𝒮subscript𝑗𝒮∇subscript𝑓𝑗𝒙\bm{g}_{i}\leftarrow\nabla f_{i}(\bm{y}_{i};\zeta)-\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x};\zeta)+\tfrac{1}{\lvert\mathcal{S}\rvert}\textstyle\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}}\nabla f_{j}(\bm{x}) for Mime. MimeLite simply uses the local minibatch gradient whereas Mime uses an SVRG style correction [26]. This is done to reduce the noise from sampling a local mini-batch. While this correction yields faster rates in theory (and in practice for convex problems), in deep learning applications we found that MimeLite closely matches the performance of Mime.

Finally, there are two modifications made in practical FL: we weight all averages across the clients by the number of datapoints nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} [41], and we perform K𝐾K epochs instead of K𝐾K steps [61].

4 Theoretical analysis of Mime

Table 1 summarizes the rates of Mime (highlighted in blue) and MimeLite (highlighted in green) and compares them to Server-Only methods when using SGD, Adam and momentum methods as the base algorithms. We will first examine the convergence of Mime and MimeLite with a generic base optimizer and show that its properties are preserved in the federated setting. We then examine a specific momentum based base optimizer, and prove that Mime and MimeLite can be asymptotically faster than the best server-only method. This is the first result to prove the usefulness of local steps and demonstrate asymptotic speed-ups.

4.1 Convergence with a generic base optimizer

We will prove a generic reduction result demonstrating that if the underlying base algorithm converges, and is robust to slight perturbations, then Mime and MimeLite also preserve the convergence of the algorithm when applied to the federated setting with additinoal local steps.

Theorem I.

Suppose that we have G2superscript𝐺2G^{2} inter-client gradient variance ((A1)), L𝐿L-smooth {fi}subscript𝑓𝑖\{f_{i}\} ((A2*)), and σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} intra-client gradient variance ((A3)). Further, suppose that the updater 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} of our base-optimizer ℬ=(𝒰,𝒱)ℬ𝒰𝒱\mathcal{B}=(\mathcal{U},\mathcal{V}) satisfies i) linearity: 𝒰​(𝐠1+𝐠2)=𝒰​(𝐠1)+𝒰​(𝐠2)𝒰subscript𝐠1subscript𝐠2𝒰subscript𝐠1𝒰subscript𝐠2\mathcal{U}(\bm{g}_{1}+\bm{g}_{2})=\mathcal{U}(\bm{g}_{1})+\mathcal{U}(\bm{g}_{2}), and ii) Lipschitzness: ∥𝒰​(𝐠)∥≤B​∥𝐠∥delimited-∥∥𝒰𝐠𝐵delimited-∥∥𝐠\lVert\mathcal{U}(\bm{g})\rVert\leq B\lVert\bm{g}\rVert for some B≥0𝐵0B\geq 0. Then, running Mime or MimeLite with K𝐾K local updates and step-size η𝜂\eta is equivalent to running a centralized algorithm with step-size η~:=K​η≤12​L​Bassign~𝜂𝐾𝜂12𝐿𝐵\tilde{\eta}:=K\eta\leq\frac{1}{2LB}, and updates

𝒙tsubscript𝒙𝑡\displaystyle\bm{x}_{t} ←𝒙t−1−η~​𝒰​(𝒈t+𝒆t,𝒔t−1), and←absentsubscript𝒙𝑡1~𝜂𝒰subscript𝒈𝑡subscript𝒆𝑡subscript𝒔𝑡1 and\displaystyle\leftarrow\bm{x}_{t-1}-\tilde{\eta}\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{g}_{t}+\text{\hbox{\pagecolor{myred!30}$\bm{e}_{t}$}},\bm{s}_{t-1})\,,\text{ and }
𝒔tsubscript𝒔𝑡\displaystyle\bm{s}_{t} ←𝒱​(𝒈t,𝒔t−1), where we have←absent𝒱subscript𝒈𝑡subscript𝒔𝑡1 where we have\displaystyle\leftarrow\mathcal{V}(\bm{g}_{t},\bm{s}_{t-1})\,,\text{ where we have}

𝔼t⁡[𝒈t]=∇f​(𝒙t−1)subscript𝔼𝑡subscript𝒈𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝒙𝑡1\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}_{t}[\bm{g}_{t}]=\nabla f(\bm{x}_{t-1}), 𝔼t∥𝐠t−∇f(𝐱t−1)∥2≤G2/S\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}_{t}\lVert\bm{g}_{t}-\nabla f(\bm{x}_{t-1})\rVert^{2}\leq G^{2}/S, and

1B2​L2​η~2𝔼t∥𝒆t∥2≤{𝔼t∥𝒈t∥2Mime ,𝔼t∥𝒈t∥2+G2+σ2KMimeLite.\tfrac{1}{B^{2}L^{2}\tilde{\eta}^{2}}\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}_{t}\lVert\text{\hbox{\pagecolor{myred!30}$\bm{e}_{t}$}}\rVert^{2}\leq\begin{cases}\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}_{t}\lVert\bm{g}_{t}\rVert^{2}&\text{\hbox{\pagecolor{myblue!30}{\sc Mime}}\,,}\\ \operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}_{t}\lVert\bm{g}_{t}\rVert^{2}+G^{2}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{K}&\text{\hbox{\pagecolor{mygreen!30}{\sc MimeLite}}.}\end{cases}

Here, we have proven that Mime and MimeLite truly mimic the centralized base algorithm with very small perturbations—the magnitude of 𝒆tsubscript𝒆𝑡\bm{e}_{t} is 𝒪​(η~2)𝒪superscript~𝜂2\mathcal{O}(\tilde{\eta}^{2}). The key to the result is the linearity of the parameter update step 𝒰​(⋅)𝒰⋅\mathcal{U}(\,\cdot\,). By separating the base optimizer into a very simple parameter step 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} and a more complicated optimizer state update step 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V}, we can ensure that commonly used algorithms such as momentum, Adam, Adagrad, and others all satisfy this property. Armed with this general reduction, we can easily obtain specific convergence results.

Corollary II ((Mime/MimeLite) with SGD).

Given that the conditions in Theorem I are satisfied, let us run T𝑇T rounds with K𝐾K local steps using SGD as the base optimizer and output 𝐱outsuperscript𝐱out\bm{x}^{\text{out}}. This output satisfies 𝔼∥∇f(𝐱out)∥2≤ϵ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x}^{\text{out}})\rVert^{2}\leq\epsilon for F:=f​(𝐱0)−f⋆assign𝐹𝑓subscript𝐱0superscript𝑓⋆F:=f(\bm{x}_{0})-f^{\star}, G~2:=G2+σ2/Kassignsuperscript~𝐺2superscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2𝐾\tilde{G}^{2}:=G^{2}+\sigma^{2}/K and

  • •

    μ𝜇\mu-PL inequality: η=𝒪~​(1μ​K​T)𝜂~𝒪1𝜇𝐾𝑇\eta=\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\big{(}\frac{1}{\mu KT}\big{)}, and

    T={𝒪~​(L​G2μ​S​ϵ+L​Fμ​log⁡(1ϵ))Mime,𝒪~​(L​G~2μ​S​ϵ+L​G~μ​ϵ+L​Fμ​log⁡(1ϵ))MimeLite.𝑇cases~𝒪𝐿superscript𝐺2𝜇𝑆italic-ϵ𝐿𝐹𝜇1italic-ϵMime~𝒪𝐿superscript~𝐺2𝜇𝑆italic-ϵ𝐿~𝐺𝜇italic-ϵ𝐿𝐹𝜇1italic-ϵMimeLiteT=\begin{cases}\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\Big{(}\frac{LG^{2}}{\mu S\epsilon}+\frac{LF}{\mu}\log\big{(}\frac{1}{\epsilon}\big{)}\big{)}&\text{\hbox{\pagecolor{myblue!30}{\sc Mime}}}\,,\\ \tilde{\mathcal{O}}\Big{(}\frac{L\tilde{G}^{2}}{\mu S\epsilon}+\frac{L\tilde{G}}{\mu\sqrt{\epsilon}}+\frac{LF}{\mu}\log\big{(}\frac{1}{\epsilon}\big{)}\big{)}&\text{\hbox{\pagecolor{mygreen!30}{\sc MimeLite}}}\,.\end{cases}
  • •

    Non-convex: for η=𝒪​(F​SL​G~2​T​K2)𝜂𝒪𝐹𝑆𝐿superscript~𝐺2𝑇superscript𝐾2\eta=\mathcal{O}\big{(}\sqrt{\frac{FS}{L\tilde{G}^{2}TK^{2}}}\big{)}, and

    T={𝒪​(L​G2​FS​ϵ2+L​Fϵ)Mime,𝒪​(L​G~2​FS​ϵ2+L2​G~​Fϵ3/2+L​Fϵ)MimeLite.𝑇cases𝒪𝐿superscript𝐺2𝐹𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝐿𝐹italic-ϵMime𝒪𝐿superscript~𝐺2𝐹𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript𝐿2~𝐺𝐹superscriptitalic-ϵ32𝐿𝐹italic-ϵMimeLiteT=\begin{cases}\mathcal{O}\Big{(}\frac{LG^{2}F}{S\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{LF}{\epsilon}\Big{)}&\text{\hbox{\pagecolor{myblue!30}{\sc Mime}}}\,,\\ \mathcal{O}\Big{(}\frac{L\tilde{G}^{2}F}{S\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{L^{2}\tilde{G}F}{\epsilon^{3/2}}+\frac{LF}{\epsilon}\Big{)}&\text{\hbox{\pagecolor{mygreen!30}{\sc MimeLite}}}\,.\end{cases}

If we take a sufficient number of local steps K≥G2/σ2𝐾superscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2K\geq G^{2}/\sigma^{2}, then we have G~=𝒪​(G)~𝐺𝒪𝐺\tilde{G}=\mathcal{O}(G) in the above rates. On comparing with the rates in Table 1 for Server-Only SGD, we see that Mime exactly matches its rates. MimeLite matches the asymptotic term but has a few higher order terms. Note that when using SGD as the base optimizer, MimeLite becomes exactly the same as FedAvg and hence has the same rate of convergence.

Corollary III ((Mime/MimeLite) with Adam).

Suppose that the conditions in Theorem I are satisfied, and further |∇jfi​(𝐱)|≤Hsubscript∇𝑗subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱𝐻|\nabla_{j}f_{i}(\bm{x})|\leq H for any coordinate j∈[d]𝑗delimited-[]𝑑j\in[d]. Then let us run T𝑇T rounds using Adam as the base optimizer with K𝐾K local steps, β1=0subscript𝛽10\beta_{1}=0, ε0>0subscript𝜀00\varepsilon_{0}>0, η≤ε02/K​L​(H+ε0)𝜂superscriptsubscript𝜀02𝐾𝐿𝐻subscript𝜀0\eta\leq\varepsilon_{0}^{2}/KL(H+\varepsilon_{0}), and any β2∈[0,1)subscript𝛽201\beta_{2}\in[0,1). Output 𝐱outsuperscript𝐱out\bm{x}^{\text{out}} chosen randomly from {𝐱1,…​𝐱T}subscript𝐱1…subscript𝐱𝑇\{\bm{x}_{1},\dots\bm{x}_{T}\} satisfies 𝔼∥∇f(𝐱out)∥2≤ϵ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x}^{\text{out}})\rVert^{2}\leq\epsilon for

T={𝒪​(L​F​(H+ε0)2ε02​(ϵ−G~2/S))Mime Adam,𝒪​(L​F​(H+ε0)2​Sε02​(ϵ−G~2/S))MimeLite Adam.𝑇cases𝒪𝐿𝐹superscript𝐻subscript𝜀02superscriptsubscript𝜀02italic-ϵsuperscript~𝐺2𝑆Mime Adam𝒪𝐿𝐹superscript𝐻subscript𝜀02𝑆superscriptsubscript𝜀02italic-ϵsuperscript~𝐺2𝑆MimeLite AdamT=\begin{cases}\mathcal{O}\Big{(}\frac{LF(H+\varepsilon_{0})^{2}}{\varepsilon_{0}^{2}(\epsilon-\tilde{G}^{2}/S)}\Big{)}&\textnormal{\hbox{\pagecolor{myblue!30}{\sc Mime} Adam}}\,,\vspace{2mm}\\ \mathcal{O}\Big{(}\frac{LF(H+\varepsilon_{0})^{2}\sqrt{S}}{\varepsilon_{0}^{2}(\epsilon-\tilde{G}^{2}/S)}\Big{)}&\textnormal{\hbox{\pagecolor{mygreen!30}{\sc MimeLite} Adam}}\,.\end{cases}\vspace{-3mm}

where F:=f​(𝐱0)−f⋆assign𝐹𝑓subscript𝐱0superscript𝑓⋆F:=f(\bm{x}_{0})-f^{\star}, G~2:=G2+σ2/Kassignsuperscript~𝐺2superscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2𝐾\tilde{G}^{2}:=G^{2}+\sigma^{2}/K.

Note that here ε0subscript𝜀0\varepsilon_{0} represents a small positive parameter used in Adam for regularization, and is different from the accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Similar to the Server-Only analysis of Adam [70], we assume β1=0subscript𝛽10\beta_{1}=0 and that batch size is large enough such that S≥G2/ϵ𝑆superscript𝐺2italic-ϵS\geq G^{2}/\epsilon. A similar analysis can also be carried out for AdaGrad, and other novel variants of Adam [40].

4.2 Circumventing server-only lower bounds

The rates obtained above, while providing a safety-check, do not beat those of the Server-Only approach. The previous best rates for cross-device FL correspond to MimeLiteSGD which is 𝒪​(L​G2S​ϵ2+L2​Gϵ3/2)𝒪𝐿superscript𝐺2𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript𝐿2𝐺superscriptitalic-ϵ32\mathcal{O}(\frac{LG^{2}}{S\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{L^{2}G}{\epsilon^{3/2}}) [32, 34, 64]. While, using a separate server-learning rate can remove the effect of the second term [31], this at best matches the rate of Server-Only SGD 𝒪​(L​G2S​ϵ2)𝒪𝐿superscript𝐺2𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ2\mathcal{O}(\frac{LG^{2}}{S\epsilon^{2}}). This is significantly slower than simply using momentum based variance reduction (MVR) as in in the FL setting (Server-Only MVR) which has a communication complexity of 𝒪​(L​GS​ϵ3/2)𝒪𝐿𝐺𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ32\mathcal{O}(\frac{LG}{\sqrt{S}\epsilon^{3/2}}) [14]. Thus, even though the main reason for studying local-step methods was to improve the communication complexity, none thus far show such improvement. The above difficulty of beating Server-Only may not be surprising given the two sets of strong lower bounds known.

Necessity of local steps.

Firstly, [5] show a gradient oracle lower bound of Ω​(L​GS​ϵ3/2)Ω𝐿𝐺𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ32\Omega(\frac{LG}{\sqrt{S}\epsilon^{3/2}}). This matches the complexity of MVR, and hence at first glance it seems that Server-Only MVR is optimal. However, the lower bound is really only on the number of gradients computed and not on the number of clients sampled (sample complexity) [16], or number of rounds of communication required. In particular, multiple local updates which increases number of gradients computed without needing additional communication offers us a potential way to side-step such lower bounds. A careful analysis of the bias introduced as a result of such local steps is a key part of our analysis.

Necessity of δ𝛿\delta-BHD.

A second set of lower bounds directly study the number of communication rounds required in heterogeneous optimization [6, 64]. These results prove that there exist settings where local steps provide no advantage and Server-Only methods are optimal. This however contradicts real world experimental evidence [41]. As before, the disparity arises due to the contrived settings considered by the lower bounds. For distributed optimization (with full client participation) and convex quadratic objectives, δ𝛿\delta-BHD ((A2)) was shown to be a sufficient [49, 48] and necessary [6] condition to circumvent these lower bounds and yield highly performant methods. We similarly leverage δ𝛿\delta-BHD ((A2)) to design novel methods which significantly extend prior results to i) all smooth non-convex functions (not just quadratics), and ii) cross-device FL with client sampling.

We now state our convergence results with momentum based variance reduction (MVR) as the base-algorithm since it is known to be optimal in the Server-Only setting.

Theorem IV.

For L𝐿L-smooth f𝑓f with G2superscript𝐺2G^{2} gradient dissimilarity ((A1)), δ𝛿\delta Hessian dissimilarity ((A2)) and F:=(f​(𝐱0)−f⋆)assign𝐹𝑓superscript𝐱0superscript𝑓⋆F:=(f(\bm{x}^{0})-f^{\star}), let us run MVR as the base algorithm for T𝑇T rounds with K≥L/δ𝐾𝐿𝛿K\geq L/\delta local steps and generate an output 𝐱outsuperscript𝐱out\bm{x}^{\text{out}}. This output satisfies 𝔼∥∇f(𝐱out)∥2≤ϵ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x}^{\text{out}})\rVert^{2}\leq\epsilon for

  • •

    MimeMVR: η=𝒪​(min⁡(1δ​K,(S​FG2​T​K3)1/3))𝜂𝒪1𝛿𝐾superscript𝑆𝐹superscript𝐺2𝑇superscript𝐾313\eta=\mathcal{O}\Big{(}\min\big{(}\frac{1}{\delta K}\,,(\frac{SF}{G^{2}TK^{3}})^{1/3})), momentum β=1−𝒪​(δ2​S2/3(T​G2)2/3)𝛽1𝒪superscript𝛿2superscript𝑆23superscript𝑇superscript𝐺223\beta=1-\mathcal{O}(\tfrac{\delta^{2}S^{2/3}}{(TG^{2})^{2/3}}), and

    T=𝒪​(δ​G​FS​ϵ3/2+G2S​ϵ+δ​Fϵ).𝑇𝒪𝛿𝐺𝐹𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ32superscript𝐺2𝑆italic-ϵ𝛿𝐹italic-ϵT=\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\delta GF}{\sqrt{S}\epsilon^{3/2}}+\frac{G^{2}}{S\epsilon}+\frac{\delta F}{\epsilon}\big{)}\,.
  • •

    MimeLiteMVR: η=𝒪​(min⁡(1δ​K,(FG^2​T​K3)1/3))𝜂𝒪1𝛿𝐾superscript𝐹superscript^𝐺2𝑇superscript𝐾313\eta=\mathcal{O}\Big{(}\min\big{(}\frac{1}{\delta K}\,,(\frac{F}{\hat{G}^{2}TK^{3}})^{1/3})), momentum β=1−𝒪​(δ2(T​G^2)2/3)𝛽1𝒪superscript𝛿2superscript𝑇superscript^𝐺223\beta=1-\mathcal{O}(\tfrac{\delta^{2}}{(T\hat{G}^{2})^{2/3}}), and

    T=𝒪​(δ​G^​Fϵ3/2+G^2ϵ+δ​Fϵ).𝑇𝒪𝛿^𝐺𝐹superscriptitalic-ϵ32superscript^𝐺2italic-ϵ𝛿𝐹italic-ϵT=\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\delta\hat{G}F}{\epsilon^{3/2}}+\frac{\hat{G}^{2}}{\epsilon}+\frac{\delta F}{\epsilon}\big{)}\,.

Here, we define G^2:=G2+σ2assignsuperscript^𝐺2superscript𝐺2superscript𝜎2\hat{G}^{2}:=G^{2}+\sigma^{2} and the expectation in 𝔼∥∇f(𝒙out)∥2≤ϵ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x}^{\text{out}})\rVert^{2}\leq\epsilon is taken both over the sampling of the clients during the running of the algorithm, the sampling of the mini-batches in local updates, and the choice of 𝒙outsuperscript𝒙out\bm{x}^{\text{out}} (which is chosen randomly from the client iterates 𝒚isubscript𝒚𝑖\bm{y}_{i}).

Remarkably, the rates of our methods are independent of L𝐿L and only depend on δ𝛿\delta. Thus, when δ≤L𝛿𝐿\delta\leq L and δ≤L/S𝛿𝐿𝑆\delta\leq\nicefrac{{L}}{{S}} for MimeMVR and MimeLiteMVR, the rates beat the server only lower bound of Ω​(L​GS​ϵ3/2)Ω𝐿𝐺𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ32\Omega(\frac{LG}{\sqrt{S}\epsilon^{3/2}}). In fact, if the Hessian variance is small and δ≈0𝛿0\delta\approx 0, our methods only need 𝒪​(1/ϵ)𝒪1italic-ϵ\mathcal{O}(\nicefrac{{1}}{{\epsilon}}) rounds to communicate. Intuitively, our results show that local steps are very useful when heterogeneity (represented by δ𝛿\delta) is smaller than optimization difficulty (captured by smoothness constant L𝐿L).

MimeMVR uses a momentum parameter β𝛽\beta of the order of (1−𝒪​(T​G2)−2/3)1𝒪superscript𝑇superscript𝐺223(1-\mathcal{O}(TG^{2})^{-2/3}) i.e. as T𝑇T increases, β𝛽\beta asymptotically approaches 1. In contrast, previous analyses of distributed momentum (e.g. [68]) prove rates of the form G2S​(1−β)​ϵ2superscript𝐺2𝑆1𝛽superscriptitalic-ϵ2\frac{G^{2}}{S(1-\beta)\epsilon^{2}}, which are worse than that of standard SGD by a factor of 11−β11𝛽\frac{1}{1-\beta}. Thus, ours is also the first result which theoretically showcases the usefulness of using large momentum in distributed and federated learning.

Our analysis is highly non-trivial and involves two crucial ingredients: i) computing the momentum at the server level to ensure that it remains unbiased and then applying it locally during every client update to reduce variance, and ii) carefully keeping track of the bias introduced via additional local steps. Our experiments (Sec. 5) verify our theoretical insights are indeed applicable in deep learning settings as well. See App. B for a proof sketch and App. F–G detailed proofs.

5 Experimental analysis on real world datasets

We run experiments on natively federated datasets to confirm our theory and accurately measure real world performance. Our main findings are i) Mime and MimeLite consistently outperform FedAvg, and ii) momentum and adaptivity significantly improves performance.

5.1 Setup

Algorithms.

We consider three (meta) algorithms: FedAvg, Mime, and MimeLite. Each of these adapt four base optimizers: SGD, momentum, Adam, and Adagrad.
FedAvg follows [46] who run multiple epochs of SGD on each client sampled, and then aggregate the net client updates. This aggregated update is used as a pseudo-gradient in the base optimizer (called server optimizer). The learning rate for the server optimizer is fixed to 1 as in [62]. This is done to ensure all algorithms have the same number of hyper-parameters.
Mime and MimeLite follow Algorithm 1 and also run a fixed number of epochs on the client. However, note that this requires communicating both the full local-batch gradient as well as the parameter updates doubling the communication required to be sent by the client. For a fairer comparison, we split the sampled clients in Mime and MimeLite into two groups–the first communicates only full local-batch gradient and the latter communicates only parameter updates. Thus, all methods have equal client communication to the server. This variant retains the convergence guarantees up to constants (details in the Appendix). We also run Loc-Mime where instead of keeping the global optimizer state fixed, we update it locally within the client. The optimizer state is reset after the round finishes. In all methods, aggregation is weighted by the number of samples on the clients.

Datasets and models. We run five simulations on three real-world federated datasets: EMNIST62 with i) a linear classifier, ii) an MLP, and iii) a CNN, iv) a charRNN on Shakespeare, and v) an LSTM for next word prediction on StackOverflow, all accessed through Tensorflow Federated [55]. The learning rates were individually tuned and other optimizer hyper-parameters such as β𝛽\beta for momentum, β1subscript𝛽1\beta_{1}, β2subscript𝛽2\beta_{2}, ε0subscript𝜀0\varepsilon_{0} for Adam and AdaGrad were left to their default values, unless explicitly stated otherwise. We refer to Appendix C for additional setup details and discussion.

5.2 Ablation and comparative study

In order to study the different algorithms, we train a 2 hidden layer (300​μ300𝜇300\mu-100100100) MLP on EMNIST62 with 10 local epochs for 1k rounds and use SGD+momentum (with tuned β𝛽\beta) as the base optimizer.

Mime ≈\approx MimeLite >> FedAvg >> SCAFFOLD >> FedProx.

Fig. 1 (left) shows Mime and MimeLite have nearly identical performance, and are about 7×7\times faster than FedAvg. This implies our strategy of applying momentum to client updates is faster than simply using server momentum. FedProx [38] uses an additional regularizer μ𝜇\mu tuned over [0.1,0.5,1]0.10.51[0.1,0.5,1] (μ=0𝜇0\mu=0 is the same as FedAvg). Regularization does not seem to reduce client drift but still slows down convergence [61]. SCAFFOLD [30] is also slower than Mime and FedAvg in this setup. This is because in cross-device setting with a large number of clients (N=3.4​k𝑁3.4𝑘N=3.4k) means that each client is visited less than 6 times during the entire training (20 clients per round for 1k rounds). Hence, the client control variate stored is quite stale (from about 200 rounds ago) which slows down the convergence.

With momentum >> without momentum.

Fig. 1 (center) examines the impact of momentum on FedAvg and Mime. Momentum slightly improves the performance of FedAvg, whereas it has a significant impact on the performance of Mime. This is also in line with our theory and confirms that Mime’s strategy of applying it locally at every client update makes better use of momentum.

Fixed >> locally updated optimizer state.

Finally, we check how the performance of Mime changes if instead of keeping the momentum fixed throughout a round, we let it change. The latter is a way to combine global and local momentum. The momentum is reset at the end of the round ignoring the changes the clients make to it. Fig. 1 (right) shows that this worsens the performance, confirming that it is better to keep the global optimizer state fixed as predicted by our theory.

Together, the above observations validate all aspects of Mime (and MimeLite) design: compute statistics at the server level, and apply them unchanged at every client update.

5.3 Large scale comparison with equal server and client communication

We perform a larger scale study closely matching the setup of [46]. For both Mime and MimeLite, only half the clients compute and transmit the updated parameters, and other half transmit the full local-batch gradients. Hence, client to server communication cost is the same for all methods for all clients. However, Mime and MimeLite require sending additional optimization state to the clients. Hence, we also reduce the number of clients sampled in each round to ensure sum total of communication at each round is 40×40\times model size for EMNIST and Shakespeare experiments, and 100×100\times model size for the StackOverflow next word prediction experiment.

Since we only perform 1 local epoch, the hyper-parameters (e.g. epsilon for adaptive methods) are more carefully chosen following [46], and Mime and MimeLite use significantly fewer clients per round, the difference between FedAvg and Mime is smaller here. Table 2 summarizes the results.

For the image classification tasks of EMNIST62 logistic and EMNIST62 CNN, Mime and MimeLite with Adam achieve the best performance. Using momentum (both with SGDm, and in Adam) significantly improves their performance. In contrast, FedAvgAdam is more unstable with worse performance. This is because FedAvg is excessively sensitive to hyperparameters (cf. App. D).

We next consider the character prediction task on Shakespeare dataset, and next word prediction on StackOverflow. Here, the momentum based methods (SGDm and Adam) are slower than their non-momentum counterparts (SGD and AdaGrad). This is because the mini-batch gradients in these tasks are sparse, with the gradients corresponding to tokens not in the mini-batch being zero. This sparsity structure is however destroyed when using momentum or Adam. For the same reason, Mime which uses an SVRG correction also significantly increases the gradient density.

Discussion.

For traditional deep learning tasks such as image classification, we observe that Mime outperforms MimeLite which in turn outperforms FedAvg. These methods are able to successfully leverage momentum to improve performance. For tasks where the client gradients are sparse, the SVRG correction used by Mime hinders performance. Adapting our techniques to work with sparse gradients (à la Yogi [70]) could lead to further improvements. Also, note that we reduce communication by naïvely reducing the number of participating clients per round. More sophisticated approaches to save on client communication including quantization or sparsification [53, 3], or even novel algorithmic innovations [1] could be explored. Further, server communication could be reduced using memory efficient optimizers e.g. AdaFactor [50] or SM3 [4].

6 Conclusion

Our work initiated a formal study of the cross-device federated learning problem and provided theoretically justified algorithms. We introduced a new framework Mime which overcomes the natural client-heterogeneity in such a setting, and can adapt arbitrary centralized algorithms such as Adam without additional hyper-parameters. We demonstrated the superiority of Mime via strong convergence guarantees and empirical evaluations. Further, we proved that a particular instance of our method, MimeMVR, beat centralized lower-bounds, demonstrating that additional local steps can yield asymptotic improvements for the first time. We believe our analysis will be of independent interest beyond the federated setting for understanding the sample complexity of non-convex optimization, and for yielding improved analysis of decentralized optimization algorithms.

  • [27] Peter Kairouz, H Brendan McMahan, Brendan Avent, Aurélien Bellet, Mehdi Bennis, Arjun Nitin Bhagoji, Keith Bonawitz, Zachary Charles, Graham Cormode, Rachel Cummings, et al. Advances and open problems in federated learning. arXiv preprint arXiv:1912.04977, 2019.
  • [28] Hamed Karimi, Julie Nutini, and Mark Schmidt. Linear convergence of gradient and proximal-gradient methods under the polyak-łojasiewicz condition. In Joint European Conference on Machine Learning and Knowledge Discovery in Databases, pages 795–811. Springer, 2016.

  • [30] Sai Praneeth Karimireddy, Satyen Kale, Mehryar Mohri, Sashank J Reddi, Sebastian U Stich, and Ananda Theertha Suresh. SCAFFOLD: Stochastic controlled averaging for on-device federated learning. In 37th International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML), 2020.

  • [35] Jakub Konečnỳ, H. Brendan McMahan, Daniel Ramage, and Peter Richtárik. Federated optimization: Distributed machine learning for on-device intelligence. arXiv preprint arXiv:1610.02527, 2016.

  • [41] Brendan McMahan, Eider Moore, Daniel Ramage, Seth Hampson, and Blaise Agüera y Arcas. Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data. In Proceedings of AISTATS, pages 1273–1282, 2017.
  • [42] Mehryar Mohri, Gary Sivek, and Ananda Theertha Suresh. Agnostic federated learning. arXiv preprint arXiv:1902.00146, 2019.

Supplementary material for Mime

Contents of Appendix
  1. A How momentum can help reduce client drift
  2. B Proof sketch
  3. C Experimental setup
  4. D Stability of methods to hyper-parameters
  5. E Technicalities
  6. F Convergence with a generic base optimizer
  7. G Circumventing server-only lower bounds

Appendix A How momentum can help reduce client drift

In this section we examine the tension between reducing communication by running multiple client updates each round, and degradation in performance due to client drift [30]. To simplify the discussion, we assume a single client is sampled each round and that clients use full-batch gradients.

Server-only approach.

A simple way to avoid the issue of client drift is to take no local steps. We sample a client i∼𝒟similar-to𝑖𝒟i\sim\mathcal{D} and run SGD with momentum (SGDm) with momentum parameter β𝛽\beta and step size η𝜂\eta:

𝒙t=𝒙t−1−η​((1−β)​∇fi​(𝒙t−1)+β​𝒎t−1),𝒎t=(1−β)​∇fi​(𝒙t−1)+β​𝒎t−1.formulae-sequencesubscript𝒙𝑡subscript𝒙𝑡1𝜂1𝛽∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒙𝑡1𝛽subscript𝒎𝑡1subscript𝒎𝑡1𝛽∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒙𝑡1𝛽subscript𝒎𝑡1\begin{split}\bm{x}_{t}&=\bm{x}_{t-1}-\eta\,((1-\beta)\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}_{t-1})+\beta\bm{m}_{t-1})\,,\\ \bm{m}_{t}&=(1-\beta)\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}_{t-1})+\beta\bm{m}_{t-1}\,.\end{split} (2)

Here, the gradient ∇fi​(𝒙t)∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒙𝑡\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}_{t}) is unbiased i.e. 𝔼⁡[∇fi​(𝒙t)]=∇f​(𝒙t)𝔼∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒙𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝒙𝑡\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}_{t})]=\nabla f(\bm{x}_{t}) and hence we are guaranteed convergence. However, this strategy can be communication-intensive and we are likely to spend all our time waiting for communication with very little time spent on computing the gradients.

FedAvg approach.

To reduce the overall communication rounds required, we need to make more progress in each round of communication. Starting from 𝒚0=𝒙t−1subscript𝒚0subscript𝒙𝑡1\bm{y}_{0}=\bm{x}_{t-1}, FedAvg [41] runs multiple SGD steps on the sampled client i∼𝒟similar-to𝑖𝒟i\sim\mathcal{D}

𝒚k=𝒚k−1−η​∇fi​(𝒚k−1)​ for ​k∈[K],subscript𝒚𝑘subscript𝒚𝑘1𝜂∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒚𝑘1 for 𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\begin{split}\bm{y}_{k}&=\bm{y}_{k-1}-\eta\nabla f_{i}(\bm{y}_{k-1})\text{ for }k\in[K]\,,\end{split} (3)

and then a pseudo-gradient 𝒈~t=−(𝒚K−𝒙t)subscript~𝒈𝑡subscript𝒚𝐾subscript𝒙𝑡\tilde{\bm{g}}_{t}=-(\bm{y}_{K}-\bm{x}_{t}) replaces ∇fi​(𝒙t−1)∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒙𝑡1\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}_{t-1}) in the SGDm algorithm (2). This is referred to as server-momentum since it is computed and applied only at the server level [25]. However, such updates give rise to client-drift resulting in performance worse than the naïve server-only strategy (2). This is because by using multiple local updates, (3) starts over-fitting to the local client data, optimizing fi​(𝒙)subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙f_{i}(\bm{x}) instead of the actual global objective f​(𝒙)𝑓𝒙f(\bm{x}). The net effect is that FedAvg moves towards an incorrect point (see Fig 2, left). If K𝐾K is sufficiently large, approximately

𝒚Ksubscript𝒚𝐾\displaystyle\bm{y}_{K} ↝𝒙i⋆, where ​𝒙i⋆:=arg​min𝒙⁡fi​(𝒙)formulae-sequence↝absentsuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖⋆assign where superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖⋆subscriptargmin𝒙subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙\displaystyle\rightsquigarrow\bm{x}_{i}^{\star}\,,\ \text{ where }\bm{x}_{i}^{\star}:=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\bm{x}}f_{i}(\bm{x})
⇒𝔼i∼𝒟⁡[𝒈~t]⇒absentsubscript𝔼similar-to𝑖𝒟subscript~𝒈𝑡\displaystyle\Rightarrow\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{i\sim\mathcal{D}}[\tilde{\bm{g}}_{t}] ↝(𝒙t−𝔼i∼𝒟⁡[𝒙i⋆]).↝absentsubscript𝒙𝑡subscript𝔼similar-to𝑖𝒟superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖⋆\displaystyle\rightsquigarrow(\bm{x}_{t}-\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{i\sim\mathcal{D}}[\bm{x}_{i}^{\star}])\,.

Further, the server momentum is based on 𝒈~tsubscript~𝒈𝑡\tilde{\bm{g}}_{t} and hence is also biased. Thus, it cannot correct for the client drift. We next see how a different way of using momentum can mitigate client drift.

Mime approach.

FedAvg experiences client drift because both the momentum and the client updates are biased. To fix the former, we compute momentum using only global optimizer state as in (2) using the sampled client i∼𝒟similar-to𝑖𝒟i\sim\mathcal{D}:

𝒎t=(1−β)​∇fi​(𝒙t−1)+β​𝒎t−1.subscript𝒎𝑡1𝛽∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒙𝑡1𝛽subscript𝒎𝑡1\bm{m}_{t}=(1-\beta)\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}_{t-1})+\beta\bm{m}_{t-1}\,. (4)

To reduce the bias in the local updates, we will apply this unbiased momentum every step k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K]:

𝒚k=𝒚k−1−η​((1−β)​∇fi​(𝒚k−1)+β​𝒎t−1).subscript𝒚𝑘subscript𝒚𝑘1𝜂1𝛽∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒚𝑘1𝛽subscript𝒎𝑡1\begin{split}\bm{y}_{k}&=\bm{y}_{k-1}-\eta((1-\beta)\nabla f_{i}(\bm{y}_{k-1})+\beta\bm{m}_{t-1})\,.\end{split} (5)

Note that the momentum term is kept fixed during the local updates i.e. there is no local momentum used, only global momentum is applied locally. Since 𝒎t−1subscript𝒎𝑡1\bm{m}_{t-1} is a moving average of unbiased gradients computed over multiple clients, it intuitively is a good approximation of the general direction of the updates. By taking a convex combination of the local gradient with 𝒎t−1subscript𝒎𝑡1\bm{m}_{t-1}, the update (5) is potentially also less biased. In this way Mime combines the communication benefits of taking multiple local steps and prevents client-drift (see Fig 2, right). Appendix B makes this intuition precise.

Appendix B Proof sketch

In this section, we give proof sketches of the main components of Theorem IV: i) how momentum reduces the effect of client drift, ii) how local steps can take advantage of Hessian similarity, and iii) why the SVRG correction improves constants.

Improving the statistical term via momentum.

Note that the statistical (first) term in Theorem IV without momentum (β=0)𝛽0(\beta=0) for the convex case is L​G2μ​S​ϵ𝐿superscript𝐺2𝜇𝑆italic-ϵ\frac{LG^{2}}{\mu S\epsilon}. This is (up to constants) optimal and cannot be improved. For the non-convex case however using β=0𝛽0\beta=0 gives the usual rate of L​G2S​ϵ2𝐿superscript𝐺2𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ2\frac{LG^{2}}{S\epsilon^{2}}. However, this can be improved to ((1+δ)​G2​FS​ϵ2)3/4superscript1𝛿superscript𝐺2𝐹𝑆superscriptitalic-ϵ234\Big{(}\frac{(1+\delta)G^{2}F}{S\epsilon^{2}}\Big{)}^{3/4} using momentum. This matches a similar improvement in the centralized setting [14, 57] and is in fact optimal [5]. Let us examine why momentum improves the statistical term. Assume that we sample a single client itsubscript𝑖𝑡i_{t} in round t𝑡t and that we use full-batch gradients. Also let the local client update at step k𝑘k round t𝑡t be of the form

𝒚←𝒚−η​𝒅k.←𝒚𝒚𝜂subscript𝒅𝑘\bm{y}\leftarrow\bm{y}-\eta\bm{d}_{k}\,. (6)

The ideal choice of update is of course 𝒅k⋆=∇f​(𝒚)superscriptsubscript𝒅𝑘⋆∇𝑓𝒚\bm{d}_{k}^{\star}=\nabla f(\bm{y}) but however this is unattainable. Instead, Mime with momentum β=1−a𝛽1𝑎\beta=1-a uses 𝒅kSGDm=𝒎~k←a​∇fi​(𝒚)+(1−a)​𝒎t−1superscriptsubscript𝒅𝑘SGDmsubscript~𝒎𝑘←𝑎∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒚1𝑎subscript𝒎𝑡1\bm{d}_{k}^{\text{SGDm}}=\tilde{\bm{m}}_{k}\leftarrow a\nabla f_{i}(\bm{y})+(1-a)\bm{m}_{t-1} where 𝒎t−1subscript𝒎𝑡1\bm{m}_{t-1} is the momentum computed at the server. The variance of this update can then be bounded as

𝔼∥𝒎~k−∇f(𝒚)∥2\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\lVert\tilde{\bm{m}}_{k}-\nabla f(\bm{y})\rVert^{2} ≲a2𝔼∥∇fit(𝒚)−∇f(𝒚)∥2+(1−a)𝔼∥𝒎t−1−∇f(𝒚)∥2\displaystyle\lesssim a^{2}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\lVert\nabla f_{i_{t}}(\bm{y})-\nabla f(\bm{y})\rVert^{2}+(1-a)\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\lVert\bm{m}_{t-1}-\nabla f(\bm{y})\rVert^{2}
≈a2G2+(1−a)𝔼∥𝒎t−1−∇f(𝒙t−2)∥2≈aG2.\displaystyle\approx a^{2}G^{2}+(1-a)\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\lVert\bm{m}_{t-1}-\nabla f(\bm{x}_{t-2})\rVert^{2}\approx aG^{2}\,.

The last step follows by unrolling the recursion on the variance of 𝒎𝒎\bm{m}. We also assumed that η𝜂\eta is small enough that 𝒚≈𝒙t−2𝒚subscript𝒙𝑡2\bm{y}\approx\bm{x}_{t-2}. This way, momentum can reduce the variance of the update from G2superscript𝐺2G^{2} to (a​G2)𝑎superscript𝐺2(aG^{2}) by using past gradients computed on different clients. To formalize the above sketch requires slightly modifying the momentum algorithm similar to [14].

Improving the optimization term via local steps.

The optimization (second) term in Theorem IV for the convex case is δ​K+Lμ​K𝛿𝐾𝐿𝜇𝐾\frac{\delta K+L}{\mu K} and for the non-convex case (with or without momentum) is δ​K+Lϵ​K𝛿𝐾𝐿italic-ϵ𝐾\frac{\delta K+L}{\epsilon K}. In contrast, the optimization term of the server-only methods is L/μ𝐿𝜇L/\mu and L/ϵ𝐿italic-ϵL/\epsilon respectively. Since in most cases δ≪Lmuch-less-than𝛿𝐿\delta\ll L, the former can be significantly smaller than the latter. This rate also suggests that the best choice of number of local updates is L/δ𝐿𝛿L/\delta i.e. we should perform more client updates when they have more similar Hessians. This generalizes results of [30] from quadratics to all functions.

This improvement is due to a careful analysis of the bias in the gradients computed during the local update steps. Note that for client parameters 𝒚k−1subscript𝒚𝑘1\bm{y}_{k-1}, the gradient 𝔼⁡[∇fit​(𝒚k−1)]≠𝔼⁡[∇f​(𝒚k−1)]𝔼∇subscript𝑓subscript𝑖𝑡subscript𝒚𝑘1𝔼∇𝑓subscript𝒚𝑘1\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\nabla f_{i_{t}}(\bm{y}_{k-1})]\neq\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\nabla f(\bm{y}_{k-1})] since 𝒚k−1subscript𝒚𝑘1\bm{y}_{k-1} was also computed using the same loss function fitsubscript𝑓subscript𝑖𝑡f_{i_{t}}. In fact, only the first gradient computed at 𝒙t−1subscript𝒙𝑡1\bm{x}_{t-1} is unbiased. Dropping the subscripts k𝑘k and t𝑡t, we can bound this bias as:

𝔼⁡[∇fi​(𝒚)−∇f​(𝒚)]𝔼∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒚∇𝑓𝒚\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\nabla f_{i}(\bm{y})-\nabla f(\bm{y})] =𝔼⁡[∇fi​(𝒚)−∇fi​(𝒙)⏟≈∇2fi​(𝒙)​(𝒚−𝒙)+∇f​(𝒙)−∇f​(𝒚i)⏟≈∇2f​(𝒙)​(𝒙−𝒚i)]+𝔼i⁡[∇fi​(𝒙)]−∇f​(𝒙)⏟=0​ since unbiasedabsent𝔼subscript⏟∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒚∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙absentsuperscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙𝒚𝒙subscript⏟∇𝑓𝒙∇𝑓subscript𝒚𝑖absentsuperscript∇2𝑓𝒙𝒙subscript𝒚𝑖subscript⏟subscript𝔼𝑖∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙∇𝑓𝒙absent0 since unbiased\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\underbrace{\nabla f_{i}(\bm{y})-\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})}_{\approx\nabla^{2}f_{i}(\bm{x})(\bm{y}-\bm{x})}+\underbrace{\nabla f(\bm{x})-\nabla f(\bm{y}_{i})}_{\approx\nabla^{2}f(\bm{x})(\bm{x}-\bm{y}_{i})}]+\underbrace{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{i}[\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})]-\nabla f(\bm{x})}_{=0\text{ since unbiased}}
≈𝔼⁡[(∇2fi​(𝒙)−∇2f​(𝒙))​(𝒚i−𝒙)]≈δ​𝔼⁡[(𝒚i−𝒙)].absent𝔼superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙superscript∇2𝑓𝒙subscript𝒚𝑖𝒙𝛿𝔼subscript𝒚𝑖𝒙\displaystyle\approx\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[(\nabla^{2}f_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla^{2}f(\bm{x}))(\bm{y}_{i}-\bm{x})]\approx\delta\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[(\bm{y}_{i}-\bm{x})]\,.

Thus, the Hessian dissimilarity ((A2)) control the bias, and hence the usefulness of local updates. This intuition can be made formal using Lemma 3.

Mini-batches via SVRG correction.

In our previous discussion about momentum and local steps, we assumed that the clients compute full batch gradients and that only one client is sampled per round. However, in practice a large number (S𝑆S) of clients are sampled and further the clients use mini-batch gradients. The SVRG correction reduces this within-client variance since

Var​(∇fi​(𝒚i;ζ)−∇fi​(𝒙;ζ)+1|𝒮|​∑i∈𝒮∇fi​(𝒙))≲L2​∥𝒚i−𝒙∥2+G2S≈G2S.less-than-or-similar-toVar∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒚𝑖𝜁∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙𝜁1𝒮subscript𝑖𝒮∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙superscript𝐿2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒚𝑖𝒙2superscript𝐺2𝑆superscript𝐺2𝑆\text{Var}\left(\nabla f_{i}(\bm{y}_{i};\zeta)-\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x};\zeta)+\tfrac{1}{\lvert\mathcal{S}\rvert}\textstyle\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})\right)\lesssim L^{2}\lVert\bm{y}_{i}-\bm{x}\rVert^{2}+\frac{G^{2}}{S}\approx\frac{G^{2}}{S}\,.

Here, we used the smoothness of fi​(⋅;ζ)subscript𝑓𝑖⋅𝜁f_{i}(\cdot;\zeta) and assumed that 𝒚i≈𝒙subscript𝒚𝑖𝒙\bm{y}_{i}\approx\bm{x} since we don’t move too far within a single round. Thus, the SVRG correction allows us to use minibatch gradients in the local updates while still ensuring that the variance is of the order G2/Ssuperscript𝐺2𝑆G^{2}/S.

Appendix C Experimental setup

C.1 Description of ablation study

We train a 2 hidden layer MLP with 300u-100 neurons on the EMNIST62 (extended MNIST) dataset [12]. The clients’ data is separated according to the original authors of the characters [10]. All methods are augmented with momentum–Mime and MimeLite use momentum in the client updates, and the others use server momentum. The momentum parameter is searched over β∈[0,0.9,0.99]𝛽00.90.99\beta\in[0,0.9,0.99]. For Adam, we fix β1=0.9subscript𝛽10.9\beta_{1}=0.9, β2=0.99subscript𝛽20.99\beta_{2}=0.99, and ϵ=10−3italic-ϵsuperscript103\epsilon=10^{-3}. For both FedProx and SCAFFOLD, β=0𝛽0\beta=0 (no server momentum) yielded the best performance. For FedAvg, Mime, and MimeLite β=0.9𝛽0.9\beta=0.9 was the fastest. For FedProx, the regularization parameter μ𝜇\mu was searched over [0.1,0.5,1]0.10.51[0.1,0.5,1] and μ=0.1𝜇0.1\mu=0.1 had highest test accuracy.

C.2 Description of large scale experiments

We perform 4 tasks over 3 datasets: i) On the EMNIST62 dataset [12] we run a convex multi-class (62 classes) logistic regression model, and ii) a convolution model with two CNN layers and two dense layers and dropout. iii) On the Shakespeare dataset, we train a single layer LSTM model with state size of 256 and embedding size of 8 to predict the next character [41]. iv) Finally, on the StackOverflow dataset [15], we train a next word prediction language model with embedding size of 96, a LSTM layer of size 670, and a vocabulary size of 1000. In all cases we report the top-1 test accuracy in our experiments.

All datasets use the metadata indicating the original authors to separate them into multiple clients yielding naturally partitioned datasets. Table 3 summarizes the statistics about the different datasets. Note that the average number of rounds a client participates in (computed as sampled clients×\timesnumber of rounds//number of clients) provides an indication of how much of the training data is seen with Shakespeare being closest to the cross-silo setting and StackOverflow representing the most cross-device in nature.

We use Tensorflow federated datasets [55] to generate the datasets. Our federated learning simulation code is written in Jax [18] and is open-sourced at redactedforanonymity. Black and white was reversed in EMNIST62 (i.e. subtracted from 1) to make them similar to MNIST. The preprocessing for Shakespeare and StackOverflow datasets exactly matches that of [46].

C.3 Practicality of experiments

In the experiments we only cared about the number of communication rounds, ignoring that Mime actually needs twice the number of bits per round and that the Server-Only methods have a much smaller computational requirement. This is standard in the federated learning setting as introduced by [41] and is justified because most of the time in cross-device FL is spent in establishing connections with devices rather than performing useful work such as communication or computation. In other words, latency and not bandwidth or computation are critical in cross device FL. However, one can certainly envision cases where this is not true. Incorporating communication compression strategies [53, 3, 31, 59] or client-model compression strategies [9, 17, 21] into our Mime framework can potentially address such issues and are important future research directions.

As we already discussed previously, we believe both the datasets and the tasks being studied here are close to real world settings since they contain natural heterogeneity. We now discuss our choice of other parameters in the experiment setup (number of training rounds, sampled clients, batch-size, etc.) Each round of federated learning takes 3 mins in the real world and is relatively independent of the size of communication [7] implying that training 1000 rounds takes 2 days even for small models. In contrast, running a centralized simulation takes about 15 mins. This underscores the importance of ensuring that the algorithms for federated learning converge in as few rounds as possible, as well as have very easy to set default hyper-parameters. Thus, in our experimental setup we keep all parameters other than the learning rate to their default values. In practice, this learning rate can be set by set using a small centralized dataset on the server (as in [22]). Thus, it is crucial for federated frameworks to be able to translate algorithms which work well in centralized settings directly to the federated setting without additinal hyper-parameter tuning. The choice of batch size being 10 was made both keeping in mind the limited memory available to each client as well as to match prior work. Finally, while we limit ourselves to sampling 20–50 workers per round due to computational constraints, in real world FL thousands of devices are often available for training simultaneously each round [7]. They also note that the probability of each of these devices being available has clear patterns and is far from uniform sampling. Conducting a large scale experimental study which mimics these alternate forms of heterogeneity is an important direction for future work.

C.4 Hyperparameter search

We run two hyper-parameter sweeps in our experiments: first a light setup which is reported in the main paper, and one we believe reflects the real world performance, and second a heavy tuning setting to showcase the performance of the methods as we vary the hyper-parameters.

Light-sweep setting (𝟗×\mathbf{9\times}).

For all SGDm methods, we pick momentum β=0.9𝛽0.9\beta=0.9. For Adam methods, we fix β1=0.9subscript𝛽10.9\beta_{1}=0.9 and β2=0.99subscript𝛽20.99\beta_{2}=0.99, and ε0=1×10−7subscript𝜀01E-7\varepsilon_{0}=$1\text{\times}{10}^{-7}$. For Adagrad we use the default initialization value of 0.10.10.1 and use ε0=1×10−7subscript𝜀01E-7\varepsilon_{0}=$1\text{\times}{10}^{-7}$. None of the algorithms use weight decay, clipping etc. The learning rate is then tuned to obtain the best test accuracy. For all experiments, unless explicitly mentioned otherwise, the learning rate is searched over a grid (9×9\times):

η∈[1,1​e−0.5,1×10−1,1​e−1.5,1×10−2,1​e−2.5,1×10−3,1​e−3.5,1×10−4].𝜂1E01𝑒0.51E-11𝑒1.51E-21𝑒2.51E-31𝑒3.51E-4\eta\in[$1$,$1e-0.5$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-1}$,$1e-1.5$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-2}$,$1e-2.5$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-3}$,$1e-3.5$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-4}$]\,.

The server learning rate for all methods is kept at its default value of 111.

Heavy-sweep setting (𝟓𝟔𝟕×\mathbf{567\times}).

For all SGDm methods, we pick momentum β=0.9𝛽0.9\beta=0.9. For Adam methods, we fix β1=0.9subscript𝛽10.9\beta_{1}=0.9 and β2=0.99subscript𝛽20.99\beta_{2}=0.99. For Adagrad we use the default initialization value of 0.10.10.1. None of the algorithms use weight decay, clipping etc. The learning rate is then tuned to obtain the best test accuracy.

For all experiments, unless explicitly mentioned otherwise, the client learning rate is searched over a grid (9×9\times):

ηclient∈[1,1​e−0.5,1×10−1,1​e−1.5,1×10−2,1​e−2.5,1×10−3,1​e−3.5,1×10−4].subscript𝜂client1E01𝑒0.51E-11𝑒1.51E-21𝑒2.51E-31𝑒3.51E-4\eta_{\text{client}}\in[$1$,$1e-0.5$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-1}$,$1e-1.5$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-2}$,$1e-2.5$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-3}$,$1e-3.5$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-4}$]\,.

Further, we also search for the server learning rate is searched over a grid (9×9\times):

ηserver∈[1×101,1​e​0.5,1,1​e−0.5,1×10−1,1​e−1.5,1×10−2,1​e−2.5,1×10−3].subscript𝜂server1E11𝑒0.51E01𝑒0.51E-11𝑒1.51E-21𝑒2.51E-3\eta_{\text{server}}\in[$1\text{\times}{10}^{1}$,$1e0.5$,$1$,$1e-0.5$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-1}$,$1e-1.5$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-2}$,$1e-2.5$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-3}$]\,.

Finally, for the adaptive methods such as Adam and Adagrad, we also tune the ε0subscript𝜀0\varepsilon_{0} parameter over a grid (7×7\times):

ε0∈[1,1×10−1,1×10−2,1×10−3,1×10−4,1×10−5,1×10−6,1×10−7].subscript𝜀01E01E-11E-21E-31E-41E-51E-61E-7\varepsilon_{0}\in[$1$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-1}$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-2}$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-3}$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-4}$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-5}$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-6}$,$1\text{\times}{10}^{-7}$]\,.

C.5 Comparison with previous results

As far as we are aware, [46] is the only prior work which conducts a systematic experimental study of federated learning algorithms over multiple realistic datasets. The algorithms comparable across the two works (e.g. FedSGD, FedSGDm, and FedAdam) have qualitatively similar performance except with one exception: FedAdam consistently underperforms FedSGDm. This difference, as we show later, is because FedAdam does not work with the default choices of hyper-parameters such as ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and requires additional tuning. As we explain in Section C.3, we chose to keep these parameters to the default values of their centralized counterparts to compare methods in a ‘low-tuning’ setting. We also point that while FedAdam struggles to perform in this setup, MimeAdam and MimeLiteAdam are very stable and even often outperform their SGD counterparts.

C.6 Additional algorithmic details

Appendix D Stability of methods to hyper-parameters

Appendix E Technicalities

We examine some additional definitions and introduce some technical lemmas.

E.1 Assumptions and definitions

We make precise a few definitions and explain some of their implications. We first discuss the two assumptions on the dissimilarity between the gradients ((A1)) and the Hessians ((A2)). Loosely, these two quantities are an extension of the concepts of variance and smoothness which occur in centralized SGD analysis to the federated learning setting. Just as the variance and smoothness are completely orthogonal concepts, we can have settings where G2superscript𝐺2G^{2} (gradient dissimilarity) is large while δ𝛿\delta (Hessian dissimilarity) is small, or vice-versa.

Our assumption about the bound on the G𝐺G gradient dissimilarity can easily be extended to (G,B)𝐺𝐵(G,B) gradient dissimilarity used by [31]:

𝔼i∥∇fi(𝒙)∥2≤G2+B2∥∇f(𝒙)∥2.\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{i}\lVert\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})\rVert^{2}\leq G^{2}+B^{2}\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x})\rVert^{2}\,. (7)

All the proofs in the paper extend in a straightforward manner to the above weaker notion. Since this notion does not present any novel technical challenge, we omit it in the rest of the proofs. Note however that the above weaker notion can potentially capture the fact that by increasing the model capacity, we can reduce G𝐺G. In the extreme case, by taking a sufficiently over-parameterized model, it is possible to make G=0𝐺0G=0 in certain settings [58]. However, this comes both at a cost of increased resource requirements (i.e. higher memory and compute requirements per step) but can also result in other constants increasing (e.g. B𝐵B and L𝐿L).

The second crucial definition we use in this work is that of δ𝛿\delta bounded Hessian dissimilarity ((A2)). This has been used previously in the analyses of distributed [49, 6, 48] and federated learning [30], but has been restricted to quadratics. Here, we show how to extend both the notion as well as the analysis to general smooth functions. The main manner we will use this assumption is in Lemma 3 to claim that for any 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} and 𝒚𝒚\bm{y} the following holds:

𝔼∥∇fi(𝒚;ζ)−∇fi(𝒙;ζ)+∇f(𝒙)−∇f(𝒚)∥2≤δ2∥𝒚−𝒙∥2.\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}\lVert\nabla f_{i}(\bm{y};\zeta)-\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x};\zeta)+\nabla f(\bm{x})-\nabla f(\bm{y})\rVert^{2}\leq\delta^{2}\lVert\bm{y}-\bm{x}\rVert^{2}\,. (8)

Here the expectation is over the choice of client i𝑖i. To understand what the above condition means, it is illuminating to define Ψi​(𝒛)=fi​(𝒛;ζ)−f​(𝒛)subscriptΨ𝑖𝒛subscript𝑓𝑖𝒛𝜁𝑓𝒛\Psi_{i}(\bm{z})=f_{i}(\bm{z};\zeta)-f(\bm{z}). Then, we can rewrite ((A2)) and (8) respectively as

∥∇2Ψi(𝒛)∥≤δ and 𝔼∥∇Ψi(𝒚)−∇Ψi(𝒙)∥2≤δ2∥𝒚−𝒙∥2.\lVert\nabla^{2}\Psi_{i}(\bm{z})\rVert\leq\delta\quad\text{ and }\quad\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}\lVert\nabla\Psi_{i}(\bm{y})-\nabla\Psi_{i}(\bm{x})\rVert^{2}\leq\delta^{2}\lVert\bm{y}-\bm{x}\rVert^{2}\,.

Thus (8) and ((A2)) are both different notions of smoothness of Ψi​(𝒙)subscriptΨ𝑖𝒙\Psi_{i}(\bm{x}) (formal definition of smoothness will follow soon). The latter definition closely matches the notion of squared-smoothness used by [5] and is a promising relaxation of ((A2)). However, we run into some technical issues since in our case the variable 𝒚𝒚\bm{y} can also be a random variable and depend on the choice of the client i𝑖i. Extending our results to this weaker notion of Hessian-similarity and proving tight non-convex lower bounds is an exciting theoretical challenge.

Finally note that if the functions fi​(𝒙;ζ)subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙𝜁f_{i}(\bm{x};\zeta) are assumed to be smooth as in [49, 6, 30], then Ψi((𝒙)\Psi_{i}((\bm{x}) is 2​L2𝐿2L-smooth. Thus, we always have that δ≤2​L𝛿2𝐿\delta\leq 2L. But, as shown in [49], it is possible to have δ≪Lmuch-less-than𝛿𝐿\delta\ll L if the data distribution amongst the clients is similar. Further, the lower bound from [6] proves that Hessian-similarity is the crucial quantity capturing the number of rounds of communication required for distributed/federated optimization.

We next define the terms smoothness and strong-convexity which we repeatedly use in the paper.

  1. (A2*)

    fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is almost surely L-smooth and satisfies:

    ∥∇fi​(𝒙;ζ)−∇fi​(𝒚;ζ)∥≤L​∥𝒙−𝒚∥, for any ​𝒙,𝒚.delimited-∥∥∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙𝜁∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒚𝜁𝐿delimited-∥∥𝒙𝒚 for any 𝒙𝒚\lVert\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x};\zeta)-\nabla f_{i}(\bm{y};\zeta)\rVert\leq L\lVert\bm{x}-\bm{y}\rVert\,,\text{ for any }\bm{x},\bm{y}\,. (9)

    The assumption ((A2*)) also implies the following quadratic upper bound on fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}

    fi​(𝒚)≤fi​(𝒙)+⟨∇fi​(𝒙),𝒚−𝒙⟩+L2​∥𝒚−𝒙∥2.subscript𝑓𝑖𝒚subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙𝒚𝒙𝐿2superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒚𝒙2f_{i}(\bm{y})\leq f_{i}(\bm{x})+\langle\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}),\bm{y}-\bm{x}\rangle+\frac{L}{2}\lVert\bm{y}-\bm{x}\rVert^{2}\,. (10)

    Further, if fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is twice-differentiable, ((A2*)) implies that ∥∇2fi​(𝒙;ζ)∥≤βdelimited-∥∥superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙𝜁𝛽\lVert\nabla^{2}f_{i}(\bm{x};\zeta)\rVert\leq\beta for any 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}.

  2. (A3)

    We assume that the intra-client gradient variance is bounded by σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}. For any client i𝑖i, the following holds almost surely at any fixed 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}:

    𝔼ζi[∇fi(𝒙;ζ)]=∇fi(𝒙),and𝔼ζi∥∇fi(𝒙;ζ)−∇fi(𝒙)∥2≤σ2.\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}_{\zeta_{i}}[\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x};\zeta)]=\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})\,,\quad\text{and}\quad\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}_{\zeta_{i}}\lVert\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x};\zeta)-\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})\rVert^{2}\leq\sigma^{2}\,.

    Note that we expect the intra-client variance to be smaller than inter-client variance and so typically σ2≤G2superscript𝜎2superscript𝐺2\sigma^{2}\leq G^{2}.

  3. (A4)

    f𝑓f satisfies the μ𝜇\mu-PL inequality [28] for μ>0𝜇0\mu>0 if:

    ∥∇f​(𝒙)∥2≥2​μ​(f​(𝒙)−f⋆).superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓𝒙22𝜇𝑓𝒙superscript𝑓⋆\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x})\rVert^{2}\geq 2\mu(f(\bm{x})-f^{\star})\,.

    Note that PL-inequality is much weaker than the standard notion of strong-convexity, and in fact is even satisfied by some non-convex functions [28].

E.2 Some technical lemmas

Now we cover some technical lemmas which are useful for computations later on. First, we state a relaxed triangle inequality true for the squared ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm.

Lemma 1 (relaxed triangle inequality).

Let {𝐯1,…,𝐯τ}subscript𝐯1…subscript𝐯𝜏\{\bm{v}_{1},\dots,\bm{v}_{\tau}\} be τ𝜏\tau vectors in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}. Then the following are true:

  1. 1.

    ∥𝒗i+𝒗j∥2≤(1+c)​∥𝒗i∥2+(1+1c)​∥𝒗j∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒗𝑖subscript𝒗𝑗21𝑐superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒗𝑖211𝑐superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒗𝑗2\lVert\bm{v}_{i}+\bm{v}_{j}\rVert^{2}\leq(1+c)\lVert\bm{v}_{i}\rVert^{2}+(1+\tfrac{1}{c})\lVert\bm{v}_{j}\rVert^{2} for any c>0𝑐0c>0, and

  2. 2.

    ∥∑i=1τ𝒗i∥2≤τ​∑i=1τ∥𝒗i∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏subscript𝒗𝑖2𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒗𝑖2\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\bm{v}_{i}\rVert^{2}\leq\tau\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\lVert\bm{v}_{i}\rVert^{2}.

Proof.

The proof of the first statement for any c>0𝑐0c>0 follows from the identity:

∥𝒗i+𝒗j∥2=(1+c)​∥𝒗i∥2+(1+1c)​∥𝒗j∥2−∥c​𝒗i+1c​𝒗j∥2.superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒗𝑖subscript𝒗𝑗21𝑐superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒗𝑖211𝑐superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒗𝑗2superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑐subscript𝒗𝑖1𝑐subscript𝒗𝑗2\lVert\bm{v}_{i}+\bm{v}_{j}\rVert^{2}=(1+c)\lVert\bm{v}_{i}\rVert^{2}+(1+\tfrac{1}{c})\lVert\bm{v}_{j}\rVert^{2}-\lVert\sqrt{c}\bm{v}_{i}+\tfrac{1}{\sqrt{c}}\bm{v}_{j}\rVert^{2}\,.

For the second inequality, we use the convexity of 𝒙→∥𝒙∥2→𝒙superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒙2\bm{x}\rightarrow\lVert\bm{x}\rVert^{2} and Jensen’s inequality

∥1τ​∑i=1τ𝒗i∥2≤1τ​∑i=1τ∥𝒗i∥2.∎superscriptdelimited-∥∥1𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏subscript𝒗𝑖21𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒗𝑖2\bigg{\lVert}\frac{1}{\tau}\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\bm{v}_{i}\bigg{\rVert}^{2}\leq\frac{1}{\tau}\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\big{\lVert}\bm{v}_{i}\big{\rVert}^{2}\,.\qed

Next we state an elementary lemma about expectations of norms of random vectors.

Lemma 2 (separating mean and variance).

Let {Ξ1,…,Ξτ}subscriptΞ1…subscriptΞ𝜏\{\Xi_{1},\dots,\Xi_{\tau}\} be τ𝜏\tau random variables in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} which are not necessarily independent. First suppose that their mean is 𝔼⁡[Ξi]=ξi𝔼subscriptΞ𝑖subscript𝜉𝑖\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[\Xi_{i}]=\xi_{i} and variance is bounded as 𝔼⁡[∥Ξi−ξi∥2]≤σ2𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscriptΞ𝑖subscript𝜉𝑖2superscript𝜎2\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[\lVert\Xi_{i}-\xi_{i}\rVert^{2}]\leq\sigma^{2}. Then, the following holds

𝔼⁡[∥∑i=1τΞi∥2]≤∥∑i=1τξi∥2+τ2​σ2.𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏subscriptΞ𝑖2superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏subscript𝜉𝑖2superscript𝜏2superscript𝜎2\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\Xi_{i}\rVert^{2}]\leq\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\xi_{i}\rVert^{2}+\tau^{2}\sigma^{2}\,.

Now instead suppose that their conditional mean is 𝔼⁡[Ξi|Ξi−1,…​Ξ1]=ξi𝔼conditionalsubscriptΞ𝑖subscriptΞ𝑖1…subscriptΞ1subscript𝜉𝑖\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[\Xi_{i}|\Xi_{i-1},\dots\Xi_{1}]=\xi_{i} i.e. the variables {Ξi−ξi}subscriptΞ𝑖subscript𝜉𝑖\{\Xi_{i}-\xi_{i}\} form a martingale difference sequence, and the variance is bounded by 𝔼⁡[∥Ξi−ξi∥2]≤σ2𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscriptΞ𝑖subscript𝜉𝑖2superscript𝜎2\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[\lVert\Xi_{i}-\xi_{i}\rVert^{2}]\leq\sigma^{2} as before. Then we can show the tighter bound

𝔼⁡[∥∑i=1τΞi∥2]≤2​∥∑i=1τξi∥2+2​τ​σ2.𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏subscriptΞ𝑖22superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏subscript𝜉𝑖22𝜏superscript𝜎2\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\Xi_{i}\rVert^{2}]\leq 2\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\xi_{i}\rVert^{2}+2\tau\sigma^{2}\,.
Proof.

For any random variable X𝑋X, 𝔼⁡[X2]=(𝔼⁡[X−𝔼⁡[X]])2+(𝔼⁡[X])2𝔼superscript𝑋2superscript𝔼𝑋𝔼𝑋2superscript𝔼𝑋2\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[X^{2}]=(\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[X-\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[X]])^{2}+(\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[X])^{2} implying

𝔼⁡[∥∑i=1τΞi∥2]=∥∑i=1τξi∥2+𝔼⁡[∥∑i=1τΞi−ξi∥2].𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏subscriptΞ𝑖2superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏subscript𝜉𝑖2𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏subscriptΞ𝑖subscript𝜉𝑖2\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\Xi_{i}\rVert^{2}]=\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\xi_{i}\rVert^{2}+\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\Xi_{i}-\xi_{i}\rVert^{2}]\,.

Expanding the above expression using relaxed triangle inequality (Lemma 1) proves the first claim:

𝔼⁡[∥∑i=1τΞi−ξi∥2]≤τ​∑i=1τ𝔼⁡[∥Ξi−ξi∥2]≤τ2​σ2.𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏subscriptΞ𝑖subscript𝜉𝑖2𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscriptΞ𝑖subscript𝜉𝑖2superscript𝜏2superscript𝜎2\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\Xi_{i}-\xi_{i}\rVert^{2}]\leq\tau\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[\lVert\Xi_{i}-\xi_{i}\rVert^{2}]\leq\tau^{2}\sigma^{2}\,.

For the second statement, ξisubscript𝜉𝑖\xi_{i} is not deterministic and depends on Ξi−1,…,Ξ1subscriptΞ𝑖1…subscriptΞ1\Xi_{i-1},\dots,\Xi_{1}. Hence we have to resort to the cruder relaxed triangle inequality to claim

𝔼⁡[∥∑i=1τΞi∥2]≤2​∥∑i=1τξi∥2+2​𝔼⁡[∥∑i=1τΞi−ξi∥2]𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏subscriptΞ𝑖22superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏subscript𝜉𝑖22𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏subscriptΞ𝑖subscript𝜉𝑖2\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\Xi_{i}\rVert^{2}]\leq 2\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\xi_{i}\rVert^{2}+2\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\Xi_{i}-\xi_{i}\rVert^{2}]

and then use the tighter expansion of the second term:

𝔼⁡[∥∑i=1τΞi−ξi∥2]=∑i,j𝔼⁡[(Ξi−ξi)⊤​(Ξj−ξj)]=∑i𝔼⁡[∥Ξi−ξi∥2]≤τ​σ2.𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝜏subscriptΞ𝑖subscript𝜉𝑖2subscript𝑖𝑗𝔼superscriptsubscriptΞ𝑖subscript𝜉𝑖topsubscriptΞ𝑗subscript𝜉𝑗subscript𝑖𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscriptΞ𝑖subscript𝜉𝑖2𝜏superscript𝜎2\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}[\lVert\sum_{i=1}^{\tau}\Xi_{i}-\xi_{i}\rVert^{2}]=\sum_{i,j}\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}\left[(\Xi_{i}-\xi_{i})^{\top}(\Xi_{j}-\xi_{j})\right]=\sum_{i}\operatorname{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}}\left[\lVert\Xi_{i}-\xi_{i}\rVert^{2}\right]\leq\tau\sigma^{2}\,.

The cross terms in the above expression have zero mean since {Ξi−ξi}subscriptΞ𝑖subscript𝜉𝑖\{\Xi_{i}-\xi_{i}\} form a martingale difference sequence. ∎

E.3 Properties of functions with bounded Hessian dissimilarity

We now study two lemmas which hold for any functions which satisfy ((A2)) and ((A3)). The first is closely related to the notion of smoothness ((A2*)).

Lemma 3 (similarity).

The following holds for any two functions fi​(⋅)subscript𝑓𝑖⋅f_{i}(\cdot) and f​(⋅)𝑓⋅f(\cdot) satisfying ((A2)) and ((A3)), and any 𝐱,𝐲𝐱𝐲\bm{x},\bm{y}:

∥∇fi​(𝒚;ζ)−∇fi​(𝒙;ζ)+∇f​(𝒙)−∇f​(𝒚)∥2≤δ2​∥𝒚−𝒙∥2.superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒚𝜁∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙𝜁∇𝑓𝒙∇𝑓𝒚2superscript𝛿2superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒚𝒙2\lVert\nabla f_{i}(\bm{y};\zeta)-\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x};\zeta)+\nabla f(\bm{x})-\nabla f(\bm{y})\rVert^{2}\leq\delta^{2}\lVert\bm{y}-\bm{x}\rVert^{2}\,.
Proof.

Consider the function Ψ​(𝒛):=fi​(𝒛;ζ)−f​(𝒛)assignΨ𝒛subscript𝑓𝑖𝒛𝜁𝑓𝒛\Psi(\bm{z}):=f_{i}(\bm{z};\zeta)-f(\bm{z}). By the assumption ((A2)), we know that ∥∇2Ψ​(𝒛)∥≤δdelimited-∥∥superscript∇2Ψ𝒛𝛿\lVert\nabla^{2}\Psi(\bm{z})\rVert\leq\delta for all 𝒛𝒛\bm{z} i.e. ΨΨ\Psi is δ𝛿\delta-smooth. By standard arguments based on taking limits [43], this implies that

∥∇Ψ​(𝒚)−∇Ψ​(𝒙)∥≤δ​∥𝒚−𝒙∥.delimited-∥∥∇Ψ𝒚∇Ψ𝒙𝛿delimited-∥∥𝒚𝒙\lVert\nabla\Psi(\bm{y})-\nabla\Psi(\bm{x})\rVert\leq\delta\lVert\bm{y}-\bm{x}\rVert\,.

Plugging back the definition of ΨΨ\Psi into the above inequality proves the lemma. ∎

Next, we see how weakly-convex functions satisfy a weaker notion of “averaging does not hurt”. This is used to get a handle on the effect of averaging of parameters in FedAvg.

Lemma 4 (averaging).

Suppose f𝑓f is δ𝛿\delta-weakly convex. Then, for any γ≥δ𝛾𝛿\gamma\geq\delta, and a sequence of parameters {𝐲i}i∈𝒮subscriptsubscript𝐲𝑖𝑖𝒮\{\bm{y}_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{S}} and 𝐱𝐱\bm{x}:

1|𝒮|​∑i∈𝒮f​(𝒚i)+γ2​∥𝒙−𝒚i∥2≥f​(𝒚¯)+γ2​∥𝒙−𝒚¯∥2, where ​𝒚¯:=1|𝒮|​∑i∈𝒮𝒚i.formulae-sequence1𝒮subscript𝑖𝒮𝑓subscript𝒚𝑖𝛾2superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒙subscript𝒚𝑖2𝑓¯𝒚𝛾2superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒙¯𝒚2assign where ¯𝒚1𝒮subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝒚𝑖\frac{1}{\lvert\mathcal{S}\rvert}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}f(\bm{y}_{i})+\frac{\gamma}{2}\lVert\bm{x}-\bm{y}_{i}\rVert^{2}\geq f(\bar{\bm{y}})+\frac{\gamma}{2}\lVert\bm{x}-\bar{\bm{y}}\rVert^{2}\,,\text{ where }\bar{\bm{y}}:=\frac{1}{\lvert\mathcal{S}\rvert}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\bm{y}_{i}\,.
Proof.

Since f𝑓f is δ𝛿\delta-weakly convex, Φ​(𝒛):=f​(𝒛)+γ2​∥𝒛−𝒙∥2assignΦ𝒛𝑓𝒛𝛾2superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒛𝒙2\Phi(\bm{z}):=f(\bm{z})+\frac{\gamma}{2}\lVert\bm{z}-\bm{x}\rVert^{2} is convex. This proves the claim since 1|𝒮|​∑i∈𝒮Φ​(𝒚i)≤Φ​(𝒚¯)1𝒮subscript𝑖𝒮Φsubscript𝒚𝑖Φ¯𝒚\frac{1}{\lvert\mathcal{S}\rvert}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\Phi(\bm{y}_{i})\leq\Phi(\bar{\bm{y}}). ∎

Appendix F Convergence with a generic base optimizer

Let us rewrite the Mime and MimeLite updates using notation convenient for analysis. In each round t𝑡t, we sample clients 𝒮tsuperscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}^{t} such that |𝒮t|=Ssuperscript𝒮𝑡𝑆\lvert\mathcal{S}^{t}\rvert=S. The server communicates the server parameters 𝒙t−1superscript𝒙𝑡1\bm{x}^{t-1} as well as the average gradient across the sampled clients 𝒄tsuperscript𝒄𝑡\bm{c}^{t} defined as

𝒄t=1S​∑i∈𝒮t∇fi​(𝒙t−1).superscript𝒄𝑡1𝑆subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡1\bm{c}^{t}=\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{t}}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}^{t-1})\,. (11)

Note that computing 𝒄tsuperscript𝒄𝑡\bm{c}^{t} (required only by Mime but not by MimeLite) itself requires additional communication. In this proof, we do not make any assumption on how 𝒄tsuperscript𝒄𝑡\bm{c}^{t} is computed as long as it is unbiased and is computed over S𝑆S clients. In particular, it can either be computed on the sampled 𝒮tsuperscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}^{t} or a different set of an independent sampled clients 𝒮~tsuperscript~𝒮𝑡\tilde{\mathcal{S}}^{t}.

Then each client i∈𝒮t𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡i\in\mathcal{S}^{t} makes a copy 𝒚i,0t=𝒙t−1superscriptsubscript𝒚𝑖0𝑡superscript𝒙𝑡1\bm{y}_{i,0}^{t}=\bm{x}^{t-1} and perform K𝐾K local client updates. In each local client update k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K], the client samples a dataset ζi,ktsuperscriptsubscript𝜁𝑖𝑘𝑡\zeta_{i,k}^{t} and

𝒚i,ktsuperscriptsubscript𝒚𝑖𝑘𝑡\displaystyle\bm{y}_{i,k}^{t} =𝒚i,k−1t−η​𝒰​(∇fi​(𝒚i,k−1t;ζi,kt)−∇fi​(𝒙t−1;ζi,kt)+𝒄t;𝒔t−1)absentsuperscriptsubscript𝒚𝑖𝑘1𝑡𝜂𝒰∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒚𝑖𝑘1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑖𝑘𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑖𝑘𝑡superscript𝒄𝑡superscript𝒔𝑡1\displaystyle=\bm{y}_{i,k-1}^{t}-\eta\mathcal{U}(\nabla f_{i}(\bm{y}_{i,k-1}^{t};\zeta_{i,k}^{t})-\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x}^{t-1};\zeta_{i,k}^{t})+\bm{c}^{t};\bm{s}^{t-1}) (Mime client update)
=𝒚i,k−1t−η​𝒰​(∇fi​(𝒚i,k−1t;ζi,kt);𝒔t−1).absentsuperscriptsubscript𝒚𝑖𝑘1𝑡𝜂𝒰∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒚𝑖𝑘1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑖𝑘𝑡superscript𝒔𝑡1\displaystyle=\bm{y}_{i,k-1}^{t}-\eta\mathcal{U}(\nabla f_{i}(\bm{y}_{i,k-1}^{t};\zeta_{i,k}^{t});\bm{s}^{t-1})\,. (MimeLite client update)

After K𝐾K such local updates, the server then aggregates the new client parameters as

𝒙tsuperscript𝒙𝑡\displaystyle\bm{x}^{t} =1S​∑i∈𝒮t𝒚i,Ktabsent1𝑆subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒚𝑖𝐾𝑡\displaystyle=\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{t}}\bm{y}_{i,K}^{t} (Update server parameters)
𝒔tsuperscript𝒔𝑡\displaystyle\bm{s}^{t} =𝒱​(𝒄t,𝒔t−1).absent𝒱superscript𝒄𝑡superscript𝒔𝑡1\displaystyle=\mathcal{V}(\bm{c}^{t},\bm{s}^{t-1})\,. (Update server statistics)

F.1 Proof of Theorem I (generic reduction)

Computing server update.
Lemma 5 (Deviation from central update.).

For a linear updater 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} for both Mime and MimeLite the server update can be written as
